117420781.value: Old Haunts of Holland
117420781.flat_value: Old Haunts of Holland
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Old Haunts of Holland is a series created in 2020, but the pieces really hit their stride in 2021. The project features in-depth stories of Holland's most historical venues — and shares much of the history that's fallen out of residents' collective memory. 

In total, the series has brought in more than 100,000 views, and has since been expanded to "Places from the Past," a statewide series that can be picked up by other publications.

Featured settings include the famous Ottawa Beach Hotel and Felt Mansion, as well as a menagerie on the shores of Lake Michigan and a lakeside electric park that many Hollanders never knew existed. The overall message? There's much more to Holland than Tulip Time.

117420781.value: Paoli's Sawyer Livingston playing for late sister Lacey
117420781.flat_value: Paoli's Sawyer Livingston playing for late sister Lacey
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: Hours before Paoli senior Sawyer Livingston was honored during the Rams' senior night festivities, he and his family buried his older sister Lacey. Through his work on the football field following her death, Livingston showcased two of the most important characteristics of the human spirit — resiliency and love. In this piece, I explore Livingston's trials throughout the process of grieving his sister, something which is still ongoing, and look back on the things that made her one of the most important people in his life.

117420781.value: Marlena's Bistro and Pizzeria
117420781.flat_value: Marlena's Bistro and Pizzeria
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Marlena's Bistro and Pizzeria received national attention when Marlena Pavlos-Hackney refused to comply with statewide COVID-19 mandates, including mask-wearing and social-distancing. The story began in December 2020 and continued into 2021 — coming to a head when Pavlos-Hackney was arrested by Michigan State Police for refusing to close her restaurant, even after her food license had been revoked and a restraining order had been issued.

Coverage of Pavlos-Hackney's case was shared across media networks, but nowhere was more timely, accurate information shared than through The Holland Sentinel, which published well over a dozen articles as the story developed in and out of courtrooms. Articles include real-time information from court documents, state departments and supporters/opponents of Pavlos-Hackney — as well as an updated, interactive timeline.

117420781.value: Commitment to local journalism continues
117420781.flat_value: Commitment to local journalism continues
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
The (Dennis-Yarmouth, MA) Register, a Wicked Local weekly newspaper serving the Mid-Cape Cod region, was faced with discontinuing its print edition. Editor Bronwen Walsh and New England Weeklies Editor Kathy Cordeiro took the opportunity to publish an Op-Ed pledging their continued community partnership in digital format and calling on readers to buy a digital subscription. "The Register and its parent company, Gannett, understand that many readers value and depend upon the news and information they find weekly in their print products. The company’s focus on digital news helps ensure continued delivery of valuable community journalism and effective platforms for advertisers. We need our community to support local journalism, buy a digital subscription, read the online edition, and see this as a critical part of our shared community." 

Categories: Opinion/Commentary; Public Service; Digital Drivers

117420781.value: 'I'm not going to stay silent anymore': A survivor of child sexual assault shares her story of trauma and resilience
117420781.flat_value: 'I'm not going to stay silent anymore': A survivor of child sexual assault shares her story of trauma and resilience
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
This is the story of Celeste Cone, a 19-year-old from Appleton who has spent the past six years dealing with the consequences of being sexually assaulted when she was 13. 

She shared her story with The Post-Crescent hoping to shine a light on her experience and provide a first-hand account of what happened to her to show how sexual assault — and the response to sexual assault — affects the entire community.

117420781.value: The believer: Arthur Madison launched a Montgomery voter registration drive  in 1944 -- and paid a price
117420781.flat_value: The believer: Arthur Madison launched a Montgomery voter registration drive  in 1944 -- and paid a price
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value:
This is the untold story of Arthur Madison, who in 1944 came to Montgomery, Alabama to organize a voting rights drive. Madison was a native of Montgomery whose life reflected much of the arc of the Black experience in the 20th century. Born outside Montgomery in 1883, his parents were former enslaved people who managed to create their own community outside the city. Madison knew Booker T. Washington, and after graduating college in 1910, he opened several businesses in Montgomery, then became one of the first participants in the Great Migration, settling in New York and earning a law degree from Columbia University. In New York, he built a legal practice and expanded his business opportunities while getting involved with Father Divine, an influential if controversial Black preacher of the 1920s and 30s. When Madison returned to Montgomery in 1944, he had the intent of developing his hometown even further, but wanted to register Black voters to get critical infrastructure into his hometown. For this, Madison drew the wrath of the white establishment. He was arrested and later stripped of his Alabama law license. But after his legal ordeal, upwards of 700 Black voters went to register in Montgomery, the first time that had happened in Jim Crow Alabama. 

This is also the untold story of the roots of the modern civil rights movement. Madison's voting rights drive drew together many people who would play key roles in the Montgomery Bus Boycott. Madison collaborated with E.D. Nixon, one of the key boycott leaders, in the voting drive. His work inspired Solomon Seay to move to Montgomery and play a key role in the movement. And he helped a seamstress and activist named Rosa Parks register to vote.  

Madison's story is a tale of how struggles and defeats often hold the seeds of future victories. Thanks to work with the DOT in Nashville, it's also a well-presented story.

117420781.value: Decades in the making, Alabama's prison crisis is bigger than declining buildings, critics say
117420781.flat_value: Decades in the making, Alabama's prison crisis is bigger than declining buildings, critics say
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
The Alabama Legislature in 2021 approved a new prison construction plan that will put three new megaprisons in the state. Supporters have long argued that new facilities were needed to stem a tide of violence in the prisons that has brought multiple lawsuits and threatens to put the correctional system under federal control. 

This story, and an associated one on the federal takeover of prisons in the 1970s, explored the roots of Alabama's prison crisis, and, through an interview with an inmate, showed how it plays out in the day-to-day lives of those who have been incarcerated. It revealed how decisions made on criminal justice policy -- in particular punishing felony thresholds -- continue to fuel the crisis.

117420781.value: After community fundraising efforts, a local man receives a dream come true
117420781.flat_value: After community fundraising efforts, a local man receives a dream come true
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: This series of articles began as an introduction to the community of a unique story of friendship that led to a fundraiser to help a local community member. That community member, Lance, is someone that many have seen in public because of his job at this small town's only big box store. Many community members have interacted with Lance because of his job, but were able through this story to learn more about Lance's passions and the challenges he faces in trying to enjoy them because of his limited mobility. The fundraiser that was begun through his friendship with a Texas hunting guide had been dormant for quite some time. The initial article was run which led to a local couple who saw the fundraiser previously deciding that the fundraiser was legitimate. That couple decided to close the entire fundraiser out to ensure Lance received the track chair that would provide him the mobility to pursue his passions. (As referenced in the second article.) The final article details the event held for the delivery of the track chair to Lance and all of the people locally who were involved along the way. The series of stories outlines how a community came together to make the dreams of one community member come true.

117420781.value: investigation of police union contracts
117420781.flat_value: investigation of police union contracts
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
As the nation turned its attention to police accountability in the wake of the killing of George Floyd, Asbury Park Press reporter Andrew Ford worked with ProPublica to produce an unprecedented analysis of police union contracts, revealing pricey perks and protections guaranteed to New Jersey cops. 
 
Ford joined Agnes Chang, Jeff Kao, Agnel Philip and Alex Mierjeski to develop a machine-learning workflow that spotted similar clauses across hundreds of police union contracts, including provisions that allowed officers to subvert state law, costing taxpayers more than $400,000 in illegal payouts.
 
Ford brought the paperwork story alive with classic shoe leather reporting, pressing local officials for explanations and prompting a state lawmaker to take action. Stonewalled by the state’s police unions, Ford still worked for fairness, making sure to include a prominent union attorney’s defense of the police contracts he crafted in scores of towns. 
 
Ford also secured a crucial interview with a town manager in an ironic position that illustrated New Jersey’s unique problems. Vincent Caruso now struggles to control the cost of his police department’s union contract after he personally banked a $342,000 payout including unused sick and vacation time upon his retirement as police chief. 
 
Thanks to a sourcing effort that involved emailing more than 30,000 police officers, Ford was tipped off to a police chief in a 10-officer department whose contract guaranteed him a $200,000 salary without working a full 40-hour week.
 
By reviewing hundreds of pages of documents, Ford identified an officer who more than doubled his base salary by working extra-duty jobs — which are bonus assignments for officers like monitoring traffic at a road construction site. The officer Ford spotted appeared to have violated his department’s policy by working 27 hours in a two-day period. When Ford asked the department about the officer’s hours, they launched an internal affairs investigation.
 
The story also brought to light an unusual retirement gift for a police chief: a solid gold badge worth more than $7,000.

117420781.value: Summer of misinformation: Polk Commissioners dispense false information about COVID, vaccine and ivermectin
117420781.flat_value: Summer of misinformation: Polk Commissioners dispense false information about COVID, vaccine and ivermectin
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: On many occasions throughout the summer, as COVID cases soared in Florida, the top elected officials in Polk County used public meetings to dispense false information about the virus, the vaccine and the parasite drug, ivermectin.   My reporting held these officials accountable for their statements, while providing correct and accurate information to the public.  Emails received through a public records request showed that one commissioner wanted to punish local doctors for refusing to prescribe ivermectin. Without this local reporting, many residents in Polk County would have not known any of this was happening.

117420781.value: Kansas Senate GOP wants to restrict local, school COVID-19 orders. What would that mean?
117420781.flat_value: Kansas Senate GOP wants to restrict local, school COVID-19 orders. What would that mean?
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: This bill was an extremely lengthy bill that overhauled Kansas’ emergency management laws in light of the pandemic. I noticed initial conversations among politicians and media coverage was focused on the GOP legislature’s attempts to restrict the Democratic governor’s emergency powers. But thanks to my due diligence in picking apart this bill and keeping track of all the work lawmakers put into it, I pounced on what I thought was the overlooked (but arguably more important) part of the bill – where local and school COVID-19 orders were targeted. And instead of just recapping the debate between some politicians, I wanted to get the reactions of people on the ground to this widely intrusive bill. Good statehouse reporting must look outside the statehouse, too. Double bylined with Rafael, former education reporter, who wrote the school portion; rest written by Titus, former statehouse reporter with the Capital-Journal and now with the Columbus Dispatch.

117420781.value: How Akron's Emilia Sykes became the future of the Ohio Democratic Party
117420781.flat_value: How Akron's Emilia Sykes became the future of the Ohio Democratic Party
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: In light of state Rep. Emilia Sykes being in her last term in the Ohio House and speculation on her running for higher office as a result, Titus wrote an in-depth profile introducing the Akron native to a statewide audience and how she rose to Democratic leadership. While certain episodes of her life and political career have been covered in short dailies throughout the years, this piece melds them all into one big story showing how her identity as a Black woman propelled her to leadership and is shaping the direction of the Ohio Democratic Party. Titus is part of the statehouse bureau for all of Gannett's Ohio papers, including the Akron Beacon Journal. He is based out of the Columbus Dispatch.

117420781.value: Doomsday, guns and Jesus Christ: Inside the ultra-right Rod of Iron Freedom Festival
117420781.flat_value: Doomsday, guns and Jesus Christ: Inside the ultra-right Rod of Iron Freedom Festival
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Hannah Phillips originally intended to cover a veterans event sponsored by the church, but knew she needed to keep an eye out for anything untoward. The church is known as the Rod of Iron Unification Church, an offshoot of the "Moonies" cult from South Korea. This church is known to put an emphasis on the AR-15 and other firearms, as they believe they are the "rods of iron" mentioned in the Bible. 

The veterans event (which Hannah also covered) turned out to be part of a 3-day "Freedom Festival", featuring guest speakers such as Teddy Daniels, Rod of Iron pastor Sean Moon, and Steve Bannon. After determining whether or not it would be safe for her to proceed, Hannah decided to stay for the entirety of the festival, heading back up to Milford again and again for the weekend. 

What resulted was an intimate look at an event centered around the passions of the alt-right, the second amendment, and a concealed carry fashion show. The following subscriber-only story met with acclaim from readers on both sides of the issue, with local residents thanking us for "finally" highlighting the absurdity of this growing religious movement (although we had covered them here and there for a few years) to the church itself thanking us for the coverage. 

Just before Thanksgiving, the church invited Hannah to come back and interview the pastor himself. He had "denied national outlets" in favor of speaking with her one on one. They spoke about his childhood, skateboarding, and the church doctrine for an upcoming series of stories. Pastor Sean Moon then invited Hannah to come back to the church for a wedding service (which took place the Sunday after Thanksgiving, complete with bullet-encrusted crowns for the bride and groom). Hannah was there, and we have an incredible series of photos resulting from that experience. 

We are now committed to following this church, as well as the plight of former members, for a series to start this month and continue through 2022. We plan to work with Crissa Shoemaker, Brittany Horn, and Kristen Roby moving forward.

117420781.value: Ongoing coverage of the death of Christian Hall at the hands of PA State Police
117420781.flat_value: Ongoing coverage of the death of Christian Hall at the hands of PA State Police
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Ever since our entire newsroom accidentally opened a video sent to us by a reader of Christian Hall getting shot and killed by police, Kathryne Rubright has committed wholeheartedly to reporting on this case as the lead reporter, with the entire newsroom staff supplementing her with visual help and feeds when necessary. 

She has gone above and beyond, building relationships with teenage activists, the local NAACP, Hall's family, and civil rights lawyers in order to bring this story to the public's attention. And her efforts recently paid off- this coverage caught the attention of Spotlight PA, who partnered with MSNBC to pursue an investigative report on this case. Our most recent coverage was picked up by USA TODAY, and we plan a future partnership with Spotlight to tell a more in depth story in time for the anniversary of Hall's death on Dec. 30.

117420781.value: My family's folk art keeps us connected, and 'chains a dragon' in the process
117420781.flat_value: My family's folk art keeps us connected, and 'chains a dragon' in the process
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
As a mixed race woman of Afro-indigenous Puerto Rican and European descent, I'm always fascinated by the many threads of cultures that makes up my family's overarching tapestry. My mother, who's father was Irish/Italian, and mother is Galician Ukrainian, comes from a family that has been continuing an ancient folk art for generations: Ukrainian pysanky eggs. 

Ahead of Easter, 2021, I sat down with three generations of women in my family to talk about the magical folklore behind the art, how its changed, and why they still do it -- for a special subscriber-only column.

This story was picked up by multiple papers in the Mid-Atlantic network, and even though its a column, I still love it. As an editor, I am so grateful for the chance to write when the mood strikes. I'm also proud to have captured a piece of my family's history. In the accompanying video, I include audio from a group video call with my mother, aunts, cousin and grandmother. It's something I'll cherish forever.

117420781.value: Adventurer, beware: Why are abandoned resorts in the Poconos so thrilling?
117420781.flat_value: Adventurer, beware: Why are abandoned resorts in the Poconos so thrilling?
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value:
The team at the Pocono Record and Gannett Mid-Atlantic came together to tell a compelling watchdog/public safety story in a unique way. This project features reporting from Brian Myszkowski, myself, and Hannah Phillips, along with editing from Tammy Paolino as well as optimization and design from Nick Siano and the Atlantic DOT. 

"Resorts in the Poconos have attracted everything from fetish parties to domestic terrorists and curious tourists. See how they fell into disrepair." leads readers into a watchdog piece featuring compelling writing, a haunting photo gallery and more for an immersive dive into the realm of dark tourism, rural blight and public safety. 

The story was also coupled with a top of funnel play on ghost stories associated with some of the abandoned resorts.

The project was picked up throughout the Mid-Atlantic, proving to be a strong subscription-getter and a great example of collaboration among newsrooms, storytelling and digital teams.

117420781.value: Milking it: PA Dairy Princesses promote dairy products, farm life
117420781.flat_value: Milking it: PA Dairy Princesses promote dairy products, farm life
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.value: Digital Optimization Team, Pocono Record, Mid-Atlantic Features
117420882.flat_value: Digital Optimization Team, Pocono Record, Mid-Atlantic Features
117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value:
"Forget about stilettos. Instead, Gabrielle Swavely's sparkly tiara pairs perfectly with muck boots, rubber gloves and a milking apron."

Pocono Record features writer Micaela Hood, Tri-County editor Melissa Lee and Mid-Atlantic features editor Tammy Paolino teamed up with the DOT to bring the story of Pennsylvania's competitive Dairy Princess circuit to life. 

Couple that dream team with relatable visuals, an in-depth design that makes cow print both chic and modern again, and a great story on "what it takes" to become PA's Dairy Princess, and you have a winner of a premium story that brings local, small town journalism to the digital age.

117420781.value: Domestic violence: How to support a loved one in danger
117420781.flat_value: Domestic violence: How to support a loved one in danger
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: We all know that domestic violence happens behind closed doors and it often takes a tragedy to bring the issue into the open. This happened in Vermont when a woman went missing and was later found dismembered in bags stowed in the converted van she and her husband of one year shared. This husband admitted to police that he had killed his wife during a trip to celebrate their first wedding anniversary. He has since been charged with murder and pleaded not guilty. The homicide is a tragedy but reporter Elizabeth Murray found a way to shine light on warning signs of domestic violence when she interviewed the woman's parents. She paired this with a Q&A with an expert on how people can support a loved one they fear is in a relationship that poses a threat to their happiness, health and life. This package brings readers real insight and useful advice on an issue that is under-reported.

117420781.value: As CSU moves to sell former Hughes land, Indigenous people are asking for the land back
117420781.flat_value: As CSU moves to sell former Hughes land, Indigenous people are asking for the land back
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
The sale of Colorado State University's land that held the former Hughes Stadium has been of high interest in Fort Collins and Northern Colorado since the last game was played in 2016. A local group of Native Americans have been advocating for the land to be returned to the Native people who once held it and they were largely ignored by the city and university as talks of what to do with the land moved forward. 

There was a lack of coverage around the group of Native Americans, what they were seeking and why they felt the land should be returned to them, so we worked to better understand the origins of the land and how it got to CSU to begin with and what the group wanted. Through doing this we went through land owner documents and Colorado land documents, along with dozens of treaties, to understand the history of the land. We spoke to a number of Native American advocates in the community to understand their perspective and pieced all the work together into one story that addressed the history, and what the group hoped for the future, of the land. Following the story, our sources thanked us for being the first news outlet to dig deep into the history of the land and give them a fair voice.

117420781.value: Fasting through finals: CSU's Muslim students juggle tests with Ramadan rituals
117420781.flat_value: Fasting through finals: CSU's Muslim students juggle tests with Ramadan rituals
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
This story looked at something that we felt didn't get enough, if any, coverage: how college students of the Muslim faith were navigating the most holy time of year with finals in the year of a global pandemic. It tells the story of two college students in Fort Collins and how they woke before sunrise and spent hours praying, along with hours studying. Ramadan only intersects with finals seasons every few years as the celebration rotates with the lunar calendar, so this story had a small window to be told. 

The students spoke of how this country and school system is Judeo-Christian based, and how getting through school -- even though religious activities allow for extensions at times -- is not easy as Muslim students. CSU had received just one request for an accommodation because of Ramadan, and these students said it's in part because they weren't comfortable requesting one.

117420781.value: PSD resignations, retirements rise after a stressful year
117420781.flat_value: PSD resignations, retirements rise after a stressful year
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: This story combined data, records and the testimony of teachers to provide a look at why people were leaving the K-12 education field -- whether they were ready to or not. I built databases of retirements and resignations from the past three years to compare how resignations and retirements looked after the full year of COVID-19 learning with other years. Speaking to various teachers on and off the record to hear how hard it was in the classroom and why some of them felt forced out, even as the field was desperate for teachers, put faces to the numbers. It also challenged the school district to speak to the issue, eventually saying they weren't concerned. However, shortages of teachers has plagued them through the start of this school year.

117420781.value: Ku Klux Klan in Michigan
117420781.flat_value: Ku Klux Klan in Michigan
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Formulation for this story didn't come out of nowhere. It started as a long-term follow up to a breaking news event in where a Catholic high school published a photo of students performing the Nazi salute, and one in full Ku Klux Klan garb. The photo, as the school stated, came from 1979. 
It sounded worthy for me to do rough research on the Klan's presence in Michigan to learn that the story is larger than what was previously assumed, and severely underreported. Another coworker offered to join as it's a fairly extensive project to undertake alone and she knew some contact to establish some more history. 
Research and gathering interviews and data took around four months and the writing process took a month to establish a clear narrative and facts. Several sites in the network picked up the article and readers flooded our inboxes with affirmations on the knowledge in this story. 
Most surprising to us and everyone else who read it, was the lack of photography and newspaper clippings on the Klan's history in Michigan. That's a venture left open in the story, purposely, to demonstrate how powerful the hate group is.
117420893.flat_value:
Formulation for this story didn't come out of nowhere. It started as a long-term follow up to a breaking news event in where a Catholic high school published a photo of students performing the Nazi salute, and one in full Ku Klux Klan garb. The photo, as the school stated, came from 1979. 
It sounded worthy for me to do rough research on the Klan's presence in Michigan to learn that the story is larger than what was previously assumed, and severely underreported. Another coworker offered to join as it's a fairly extensive project to undertake alone and she knew some contact to establish some more history. 
Research and gathering interviews and data took around four months and the writing process took a month to establish a clear narrative and facts. Several sites in the network picked up the article and readers flooded our inboxes with affirmations on the knowledge in this story. 
Most surprising to us and everyone else who read it, was the lack of photography and newspaper clippings on the Klan's history in Michigan. That's a venture left open in the story, purposely, to demonstrate how powerful the hate group is.

117420781.value: 'It's like you're climbing the gallows': The 'walk of shame' some theme park visitors dread
117420781.flat_value: 'It's like you're climbing the gallows': The 'walk of shame' some theme park visitors dread
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Nearly three-quarters of American adults are overweight, obese or severely obese, according to the latest numbers from the CDC. Still people of size continue to be marginalized in all walks of life, including at theme parks where guests pay to play but can end up walking away hurt and embarrassed when they literally don't fit in. This story sheds light on the challenges and shame plus-size travelers can face simply trying to have a good time like everyone else, but also how they show up for each other to help other navigate the world better. It also offers a challenge to people who run theme parks to make attractions more accessible to all.  

It also sparked this follow up story:
https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/news/2021/10/06/plus-size-travel-experience-tips-community/6005275001/

Note: Josh Rivera was the editor for both stories.

117420781.value: 'Can't be broken': The lives of the Indy Steelers football team
117420781.flat_value: 'Can't be broken': The lives of the Indy Steelers football team
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
For nearly two years, IndyStar photojournalist Mykal McEldowney followed the Indy Steelers youth football team. He embedded with the players and their families at practices and games; inside their homes; at funerals; and at birthday parties and cookouts.

Too often too many of these boys on the Indy Steelers football team experience trauma. Most of the players also navigate a world entrenched in poverty; some don’t know when their next meal is coming or where they might lay their heads at night. Though most of them range in age from 7 to 14, they have already attended far too many funerals for teammates, siblings and parents.

McEldowney shows you a father, exhausted from working third shift, washing the dishes as he cares for his kids all alone. Two children watching the coffin lid lowered for the mother they will grow up without. But he also shows you the smiles when these kids play football.

Everyone counted these kids out. But this 38th Street football team defies expectations.

117420781.value: Fourth & Goal
117420781.flat_value: Fourth & Goal
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
This short documentary follows the lives of three families with children on the Indy Steelers, "Indianapolis' grittiest urban football team. Though most of them range in age from 7 to 14, they have already attended far too many funerals for teammates, siblings and parents. They're coached by Donnell Hamilton, who knows the challenges these boys face, the dangers lurking from bullets, errant or intended, or the often-enticing drug trade. He’s lived it. 

You need to see with your own eyes a father, exhausted from working third shift, washing the dishes as he cares for his kids all alone. You need to bear witness as two children see the coffin lid lowered for the mother they will grow up without. And you need to see the smiles when these kids play football.

“This is the group of kids that everyone counted out. This is the group of kids that people thought wasn’t going to make it,” team mom Takarra Delaney said. “The heart and soul of that team is caring about those kids. It’s not just the sport. The sport is the reason we probably get together, but the reason we stay together is because there’s a love and a bond there that can’t be broken.”

117420781.value: 'Foxes guarding a hen house': Beaver Falls woman gets released then sent back to prison
117420781.flat_value: 'Foxes guarding a hen house': Beaver Falls woman gets released then sent back to prison
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: Wanda Solomon's story sheds light on corruption in the federal criminal justice system. After serving more than a decade in federal prison, Solomon was eligible for early release on her 60th birthday in 2019. After only being out of prison for one month, federal officers came to Solomon's half-way house to take her back to prison, though she hadn't committed any additional crimes. Official documents say Solomon was accidentally released. Criminal justice reform advocates say it is evidence of a systemic issue.

117420781.value: Food critic unveiled
117420781.flat_value: Food critic unveiled
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value:
For 41 years, restaurant reviews in The News-Press were written under the pseudonym “Jean Le Boeuf.” For 15 of those 41 years, that pseudonym was used to hide food writer Annabelle Tometich. 

In February, that changed. Tometich revealed herself as The News-Press’s longtime restaurant critic and the face behind the Le Boeuf pen name. In this essay, she points out the allure a fake name — one many assumed belonged to a white, Frenchman — had for a biracial woman like herself. In vivid, poignant detail, she talks about what drew her to the pseudonym, how she cherished the invisibility it gave her, and why she ultimately had to shed it. 

Tometich’s piece lit a spark in this community and around the country. Hundreds of emails and messages poured in thanking Tometich for her candor, from longtime readers to university vice presidents to new fans from Key West to Canada. The piece led to a spot on the USA TODAY Storytellers stage and a guest op-ed in the Washington Post.

117420781.value: A rare look inside COVID care
117420781.flat_value: A rare look inside COVID care
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, Muskingum County has been one of the hardest hit in Ohio. During the most recent surge, the hospital was facing a severe shortage of beds and staff due to the number of hospitalized COVID-19 patients. At the same time, the vaccine rate in the area had stalled.

 
The reporter worked with the local hospital, which serves six counties, to visit the critical care unit. The reporter was given access to doctors and nurses who talked about their experiences, and how the vast majority of their patients would likely die. A patient’s family, who didn’t want to be identified, allowed us to photograph an intubated man in the unit. He was not expected to live. This story brought home the consequences of the disease locally, and painted a vivid picture of what the pandemic really looks like.

117420781.value: LPGA: How misguided course setups are holding back women’s golf
117420781.flat_value: LPGA: How misguided course setups are holding back women’s golf
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Beth Ann's deep dive into why women's professional golf courses are not routed correctly for female players wasn't just an interesting read, it was an industry changer. Showing data that proved that golf courses are not equal for men's and women's players — for example, even the longest women's players had to use fairway woods to reach some par-4s, but many courses are setup so men's players can reach the par-5 holes in two — Beth Ann interviewed dozens of players and administrators. The result was something significant, a story that was covered heavily in the golf community (she appeared on Golf Channel and numerous podcasts and radio shows to discuss it) and the result was a different layout for the U.S. Women's Open, featuring a shorter, more suitable layout. This was also a national centerpiece for the network, with many sites using it. I added the Naples Daily News.

ADDITIONALLY, Beth Ann is the lone full-time reporter still on the LPGA beat, yet she hardly rests or takes her foot off the gas. She's constantly breaking national stories and this year was named the first female president for the Golf Writers Association of America. She's currently advocating for a lower age limit for the women's Senior Open. Don't be surprised if it happens. She's that influential.

117420781.value: "For years, Florida collected millions for condo owner education. Lawmakers diverted the money instead."
117420781.flat_value: "For years, Florida collected millions for condo owner education. Lawmakers diverted the money instead."
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.value: Jeffrey Schweers of the Tallahassee Democrat: https://amp.tallahassee.com/amp/7914810002
117420882.flat_value: Jeffrey Schweers of the Tallahassee Democrat: https://amp.tallahassee.com/amp/7914810002
117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value: This is an investigative piece that came about after I began researching Florida's condo laws in the aftermath of the Surfside condo tower collapse. Upon asking a condo association lobbyist about the purpose of the annual condo fees the state of Florida collects, he said that millions of dollars were being diverted every year into the state's general fund where there is no way to track how that money is spent. With the help of Jeffrey Schweer's Gannett's Florida legislature beat reporter, we were able to find out exactly how much money had been diverted each of the past several years, as well as a history of how the practice began. This finding, which had never been reported before, was significant because those funds could have been used for investigating complaints as well as educating condo association members throughout the state on the importance of maintaining their buildings to reduce the chances of further condo collapses. The story ran in several Gannett papers throughout Florida and was also picked up nationally by various media outlets including USA Today and Fox News. The Florida Bar's condo law safety advisory board, formed in the wake of the Surfside condo collapse, also included among its recommendations that the state Legislature halt its practice of diverting money from the Florida condo fund (see page 27 of the task force's report).

117420781.value: "Designed to fail: How Florida's lack of condo board oversight could mean another Surfside"
117420781.flat_value: "Designed to fail: How Florida's lack of condo board oversight could mean another Surfside"
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: This was a comprehensive look at Florida's condominium laws, how they came to be, and how the safeguards originally intended to ensure the safety of the residents, eroded over the years, including the state Legislature's practice of routinely diverted millions of dollars collected each year in fees from condo owners to the general fund instead of using the money to educate condo association board members as well as for investigating complaints. The erosion of the safeguards and lack of independent oversight of how Florida's hundreds if not thousands of oceanfront condo towers has resulted in the growing likelihood that more building collapses could be in the Sunshine State's future.

117420781.value: "Asian Americans aren't here for you to objectify, ridicule or kill in Atlanta shootings"
117420781.flat_value: "Asian Americans aren't here for you to objectify, ridicule or kill in Atlanta shootings"
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: First-person piece offering my perspective as an Asian American in the aftermath of the Atlanta spa shootings where eight people were killed, including six women of Asian descent. I wrote about how there seemed to be a noticeable increase in anti-Asian sentiment, both nationally as well as in the Daytona Beach, Florida, area where I now live and work. Also, I wanted readers to understand that not all Asian Americans are the same and often don't fit the stereotypes portrayed in some movies and TV as well as perpetuated by some politicians. My Op-Ed piece was picked up by other Gannett publications nationally including USA Today and resulted in my getting emails for readers from throughout the country.

117420781.value: The Last Responder: How a pandemic upended the business of death
117420781.flat_value: The Last Responder: How a pandemic upended the business of death
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: Photographer Deb Cram and writer Hadley Barndollar explored the one year into the pandemic,  to document the intimacy of a funeral home director’s work amid the coronavirus. They met with Jeff Pelkey, the funeral home director on many occasions to give readers a chance to see what they never get to; behind the scenes of a person who works with death on a daily basis such as retrieving the body, caring for it, preparing it for viewing and putting it to rest. The projects contains still photography, videos and a photo gallery.

117420781.value: This Old House
117420781.flat_value: This Old House
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
After writing about another historic home in Monroe, Michigan, I was contacted by the current owner of this home on Monroe's Hurd Rd. I toured the home and spoke at length with both the current and previous home owners. The past owner had collected a briefcase full of documents that I examined. Documents included the home's deed, documents from past owners and photos of renovation. I spent nearly a year, on and off, researching this home. I spoke with the local Register of Deeds office, a local man who constructed a map of this area from the time the original structure was built and reviewed documents in the extensive archival collection of The Monroe News. I consulted with two staff members of the Monroe County Museum System, another past owner who had several relics from the home, historians from the River Raisin National Battlefield Park and others. I read the handwritten will of early homeowner Munson Hurd on Ancestry.com.
Although my work did not uncover the questions sought by the homeowners, I was able to locate the English-embossed powder gun that was found on the property years ago. The previous two owners had lost track of this precious relic from the past, which is now in Texas.

117420781.value: The Secret History of Worcester Hip-Hop: A conversation with the City's first wave of rappers and DJs
117420781.flat_value: The Secret History of Worcester Hip-Hop: A conversation with the City's first wave of rappers and DJs
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: A portrait of the early days of the hip-hop genre in Worcester, Mass.: How it came to the city from New York, and what it meant to a generation of young people living in the city's housing projects and some of its poorest neighborhoods. The conversations were held over the course of a year, and they create a portrait of a community facing adversity through art and joy, rather than the stereotypical depictions of urban life.

117420781.flat_value: Hometown Heroes 2021
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.value: Telegram & Gazette Local News Team, the Telegram & Gazette/Worcester Magazine features team, photo department, freelance contributors Stephanie Jarvis and Liz Fay
117420882.flat_value: Telegram & Gazette Local News Team, the Telegram & Gazette/Worcester Magazine features team, photo department, freelance contributors Stephanie Jarvis and Liz Fay
117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value: A collaboration between the staffs of the newsroom staff of the Telegram & Gazette and the staff of Worcester Magazine (an affiliated periodical which is managed by the Telegram & Gazette newsroom), along with a handful of freelancers, to create profiles of eight people, recommended by community members who made a deep difference in their community, often with little or no public praise. The package also included an introduction by Worcester Magazine content editor Victor D. Infante noting another local hero  – Worcester Police Officer Enmanuel "Manny" Familia, who had died earlier in the year  – putting the other honorees in context. The 2021  honorees included Prof. Megan Ross of the Worcester Hip-Hop Congress; Déborah González, director of Community Engagement at Quinsigamond Community College; Imam Asif Hirani, the Worcester Islamic Center; Mari Gonzalez, Director of Operations, El Buen Samaritano Food Program; Joe Prochillo, vice chair, Commission on Accessibility; Dr. Erik Garcia, advocate for the homeless; Woodrow Adams Jr., creator of 508 Forever Young; and the Worcester Community Fridges program.

117420781.value: Voices from the Haunted City: We talk to the spirits of Worcester about the municipal election
117420781.flat_value: Voices from the Haunted City: We talk to the spirits of Worcester about the municipal election
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value: Written as part of Worcester Magazine's 2nd, "Halloween Guide to the Worcester Election," this story took an offbeat and whimsical approach toward eyeing the cultural and political forces shaping the city's election: Enlisting occult professionals to help Worcester Magazine content editor Victor D. Infante interview the ghosts and spirits that haunt the city. Accompanied by photographer Christine Peterson, whose photographs helped set the tone and bring a sense of cohesiveness to the package, Infante and the occultists journeyed across the city: Talking to the spirits of the dead on the Worcester common, which contains one of the city's oldest graveyards; talking to the spirits of old buildings and the spirit of the city itself; and finally sitting down with a witch for a tarot card reading for the election. The goal was never to prove or disprove the occult, but rather to take it at face value and use the conversations as a way to shake up how readers viewed what otherwise could be a conventional local election.  For a sidebar story, Infante invited every person running for City Council and the School Committee to participate in an escape room. He found three takers, including one incumbent.

117420781.value: This Old House/Hurd Road home may date back to 1790
117420781.flat_value: This Old House/Hurd Road home may date back to 1790
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
After writing a story about another historic Monroe County home, I was contacted by Suzanne Hayford, who asked me to research the history of her home, which, she was told, was originally built in 1790. I toured the home and spoke extensively with Hayford and two past owners of the home. One past owner had amassed a briefcase full of research and documents that I examined. Documents included the home’s deed, old maps and research he’d collected. Then, for the next year, I researched, on and off, this home. I worked with the local Register of Deeds and two staff members of the Monroe County Museum System. I consulted a staff member at the River Raisin National Battlefield Park, two retired historians and a local man who made an early map of the area where the home is located. I sifted through the extensive archival collection from The Monroe News to look up all names associated with the home. I read the hand-written will of past owner Munson Hurd on Ancestry.com and worked with researchers at the Historical Society of Michigan and researchers in Canada.
While my work was not able to answer the current owner’s question about who built her home, I was able to locate the English-embossed powder gun from the War of 1812, which had been found years ago on the property by a previous owner. The home’s last two owners had lost track of this precious item, which is now in Texas.

117420781.value: Valentine's Day Fun Run
117420781.flat_value: Valentine's Day Fun Run
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
The Valentine’s Day Fun Run was a spot news feature. The reporter used a short video piece to illustrate the humor and enthusiasm the runners maintained amid the extreme winter weather conditions of the day.
Several runners had signed up in advance through a gym they belonged to for a “run on your own” charity fundraiser on Valentine’s Day, Sunday, Feb. 14, 2021. They chose Sterling State Park just off Lake Erie in Michigan as their gathering spot, inviting The Monroe News to meet them at the trail entrance and write a feature. 
Paula Wethington was the reporter assigned to get a story and photos for the print edition.
The weather that day was 20 degrees, with wind chill around 12 degrees. This was so cold the runners decided on a much shorter route than they originally planned, but insisted on still doing the event in costume. As the video and article related, there actually was ice fishing taking place in shanties on the frozen lagoon just off camera. 
After looking through images she got via iPhone at the trail entrance and a bridge that is part of the popular trail, Wethington made title slides in Canva and did the video editing, splicing and voiceover with iMovie.
This was among the last “on assignment” features that Wethington worked on as a reporter. She has since taken a job as a digital producer for the Gannett Michigan Web Team.

117420781.value: How a cryptocurrency tycoon tried to work Nevada's elite to get his own government
117420781.flat_value: How a cryptocurrency tycoon tried to work Nevada's elite to get his own government
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Back in September 2020, Jeff Berns, the CEO of Blockchains Inc.,  introduced Nevada Gov. Steve Sisolak to a big idea — a proposed 35,000-person, Blockchains-owned “smart city,” complete with its own energy and transportation grid, on 5,000 acres of mountainous desert in Storey County outside of Reno. 

He pitched Sisolak on his futuristic vision for a digitally driven smart city, an idea Berns has been trying to get to stick since he bought land for the city in 2018. Berns says the city would run entirely on blockchain technology, while generating billions of dollars in much-needed new revenue for the governor’s unsteady budget. 

Four months and many billable lobbying hours later, the first-term Democrat used part of his State of the State address to sell residents on the idea of “Innovation Zones” — a new, county-like jurisdiction tailor-made for Berns and others seeking to build their own city independent from traditional government oversight. 

The proposal raised many important questions. 

How could a company simply assume the role of a local government? And why would Nevada entrust that kind of power to a man like Jeff Berns? And, to that point, just who was is Jeff Berns anyway? 

While many national and local outlets focused on the outlandish proposal with just a surface understanding (which included a notable 3-minute monologue by Stephen Colbert) the Reno Gazette Journal saw an major need to dig deep into Berns' and Sisolak's vision, which was still ill-defined and extremely controversial early into the 81st session of the Nevada Legislature. As a result, we started a team investigation, which included trips to a Los Angeles courthouse, interviews with dozens of people and, eventually, a thorough and consequential investigative series. 

The initial three-part series set out to do three things: Show how Berns used some of the most connected political actors in the state to get his idea into the governor's state of the state address in the middle of a pandemic. We then dug into the fraught business and political relationships that had emerged between Berns and Lance Gilman — a Storey County Commissioner and businessman who oversees the Storey County industrial park that now houses companies like Tesla, Google and Switch, located near Berns' planned "smart city." Last, we dug into Berns' colorful past, telling the story of a businessman who got his start busing the elderly from Southern California to Las Vegas bingo halls to defending clients as a personal injury attorney to running a bawdy telephone dating service that ended in scandal. In the course of our reporting, we would learn Berns and his wife were facing a lawsuit filed by their nanny, accusing the couple of sexual harassment. 

After the RGJ series and follow up story about the lawsuit, the proposal ground to a halt in the halls of the Nevada Legislature and instead turned into an interim study for lawmakers. 

It's for all of these reasons we believe reporters James DeHaven, Jason Hidalgo and Ed Komenda deserve to be recognized for outstanding, and consequential, investigative reporting.

In the course of our reporting, we would learn Berns and his wife were facing a lawsuit filed by their nanny, accusing the couple of sexual harassment. 

After the RGJ series and follow up story about the lawsuit, the proposal ground to a halt in the halls of the Nevada Legislature and instead turned into an interim study for lawmakers. 

It's for all of these reasons we believe reporters James DeHaven, Jason Hidalgo and Ed Komenda deserve to be recognized for outstanding, and consequential, investigative reporting.

117420781.value: Our Year in Covid
117420781.flat_value: Our Year in Covid
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value:
On March 5, 2020, the first cases of the novel coronavirus appeared in the Reno and Las Vegas areas. Weeks later, the lives of Nevadans and people across the world would be upended. In Nevada, the tourism-based economy ground to a halt. Unemployment spiked. Months later thousands would be dead. A year after those first cases appeared, the Reno Gazette Journal published a comprehensive retrospective series on the pandemic and what it took from Nevadans as well as how it forced them to adapt to a new way of living. 

The entire newsroom participated in the effort, producing 17 stories (including visual storytelling and columns). The series was comprehensive and incorporated investigative journalism, heart-wrenching narrative storytelling, and one-of-a-kind interviews with the people who led our community through the pandemic. 

The two centerpiece stories focused on a family who had to fight to say goodbye to their matriarch of their family in person. The second dove into the inequities of how COVID-19 ravaged some communities more than others in Reno-Sparks. Many of the stories highlighted Nevadans has they adapted to a new way of life, looking for silver linings where they could and grieving where they could not. We're deeply proud of this series, which was honored by the Nevada Press Association in September 2020 with a Story of the Year award. 

In short, it was the essence of local journalism at its finest. Thank you for your consideration.

117420781.value: AFTER CALDOR: The fire that jumped the crest
117420781.flat_value: AFTER CALDOR: The fire that jumped the crest
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420882.label: Other publications/teams that contributed to the work

117420893.value:
On Aug. 14, the Caldor Fire started near Pollock Pines, midway between Sacramento and Lake Tahoe. In just a few weeks, Caldor scorched more than 221,000 acres, an area larger than New York City, as it traveled more than 40 miles toward Tahoe, the largest alpine lake in North America.

The fire forced roughly 50,000 people on the Highway 50 corridor and in the Lake Tahoe Basin to evacuate. Nearly 32,000 structures were threatened, 81 were damaged and more than 1,000 were destroyed. And the Caldor did something only one fire – the almost 1 million-acre Dixie Fire – had ever done. It crested the Sierra Nevada, burning from the western slope onto the eastern slope, forever changing what officials and residents know about predicted wildfire patterns.

Reporter Amy Alonzo and investigations editor Ed Komenda spent weeks working on this 30,000 foot view of the most destructive fire to enter the Lake Tahoe basin in modern history. Alonzo set out to answer three key questions: What happened, what we learned and what needs to happen next. What followed was the most comprehensive analysis of the fire to date, showing just how big a problem the Sierra Nevada will face in the coming years as climate change worsens and human activity threatens ecosystems and communities in ways we never thought imaginable a generation ago. 

This project showcases the RGJ's strength as a news organization that can go deeper and explain the world in ways other local and national outlets can't when it comes to our region. We enthusiastically hope Alonzo and Komenda are recognized for their work.

117420781.value: Dying alone: A year of lost goodbyes for Nevada families who go without closure amid COVID-19
117420781.flat_value: Dying alone: A year of lost goodbyes for Nevada families who go without closure amid COVID-19
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
There are few journalists who can get people to open up about the worst moments of their lives to help the public better understand the stakes of an emergency. Siobhan McAndrew is one of those journalists whose empathy, news judgement and storytelling ability combined make her a unique talent and a treasure for Northern Nevada. As part of a week-long series marking the anniversary of COVID-19's arrival in Northern Nevada, McAndrew told the story that came to define the pandemic: The isolated suffering of people dying from the disease and the helpless family members hoping for a final meeting with their loved one — often to no avail. 

McAndrew told the story of the Dover family, who lost their matriarch last year. From McAndrew's story: 

"The nightmare of COVID-19 started in early November for Dover and his family, just as cases were surging in Nevada and overwhelming the health care system.    

"(Lou) Dover’s mother, his mother-in-law and a neighbor all died from COVID-19 between Nov. 16 and Dec. 19. But he was sure the sweet girl he fell in love with and married when she was just 17 would walk out of that hospital.

"Judy Dover, 57, never came home. She died on Christmas Eve, 16 days after entering the hospital."

The story she tells from there is heart wrenching, but necessary. A memorial for one family, but also an acknowledgement of the pain countless families have felt since the pandemic began. McAndrew deserves to be recognized for her storytelling ability and public service in the course of her reporting. Thank you for your consideration.

117420781.value: Ku Stevens' 'Remembrance Run' from the Stewart Indian School to honor his great grandfather
117420781.flat_value: Ku Stevens' 'Remembrance Run' from the Stewart Indian School to honor his great grandfather
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
Ku Stevens, a high school senior from rural Nevada, gained national attention when he organized a 'Remembrance Run'  to honor the memories of family members who had been removed from their families and sent to Stewart Indian School in Carson City, Nev. The school, on the southern edge of Nevada's capital, operated from 1890 to 1980 and was intended to force the assimilation of Native Americans. It was one of about 350 across the country and Canada.

Stevens' great-grandfather, Frank "Togo" Quinn, escaped from the school three times, the first when he was 8 years old, to find his way back to his family, 50 miles away across the desert. The third time he escaped, he was shackled to another student.

Reporter Jim Krajewski and visual journalist Jason Bean captured Stevens' run in great detail, producing stories and a mini-documentary about it. They help drive attention to the student's cause, keeping the important in the news and telling it with care — something that became more important after disturbing revelations came to light in Canada about the mass burials of students at those schools. The U.S. government is now conducting a similar investigation into the Stewart Indian School. 

To help capture the run from Carson City to Yerington in the middle of August and Nevada's unforgiving desert, Bean rented an electric bike to keep up with the runners while also giving himself enough time to capture footage and conduct interviews. The end product is more than deserving for recognition by Krajewski's and Bean's colleagues. Thank you for your consideration.

117420781.value: He spent 6 years in prison for a crime he didn't do. Now every move feels like a gamble
117420781.flat_value: He spent 6 years in prison for a crime he didn't do. Now every move feels like a gamble
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
For eight months in 2021, I followed Anthony Miller, a Black man in Rochester wrongfully convicted of armed robbery and sentenced to 10 years in prison.

Miller lost six and a half years of his youth due to eyewitness testimony even though there was no evidence linking him to the crime. Anthony was the first Black man encountered by police after the robbery. It could have been any Black man in Rochester.

Now that he's free, Anthony lives in a constant state of paranoia as he tries to attain some sense of normalcy. His youthful dreams have faded, and all he has left is an urge to hold the justice system accountable.

This story told through text, audio clips, and a five-minute video, tells the story of the night he was arrested, his fight for justice behind bars, and internal struggles to find a sense of place now that he's free.

117420781.value: Who's to blame for staff shortages at Reno restaurants? Here's why restaurants are still understaffed
117420781.flat_value: Who's to blame for staff shortages at Reno restaurants? Here's why restaurants are still understaffed
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
One of the biggest economic stories that came to define 2021 was the persistent shortage of labor across U.S. industries. No where was that felt more than the service sector — especially restaurants. The story played well in social media circles, especially as business owners posted signs claiming they lacked staff because no one wanted to work anymore. The truth was far more complicated as reporter Evan Haddad found out through his meticulous and well-told reporting. 

Haddad joined the Reno Gazette Journal in June and hit the ground running as our food and drink reporter. He found several examples of businesses in need of employees and the challenges of keeping the light on in an already precarious business without a global pandemic. Haddad also spoke to workers about how their lives had changed since March 2020 as we as experts who could put the entire situation into perspective. What developed was the most thorough storytelling of a complicated situation for our local audience. In the end, Haddad gave our readers the needed context about the situation instead of just relying on some emotional social media posts.

117420781.value: Death row inmate Julius Jones' fight for life
117420781.flat_value: Death row inmate Julius Jones' fight for life
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
This series of videos shows the progression of Oklahoma death row inmate Julius Jones' fight for clemency. His claims of innocence from the 1999 murder of Paul Howell gained national attention, and these videos show the steps that Jones and his supporters took to find justice.

At the start of 2021, Jones' supporters delivered signatures to the Oklahoma Pardon and Parole board, asking the board to review the case. By Nov. 18. 2021, Julius Jones had eaten his last meal and was prepared to be executed. Less than four hours before he was scheduled to die, Oklahoma Gov. Kevin Stitt announced he would commute Jones' sentence to life without the possibility of parole. 

These videos show the reactions from Jones' supporters throughout the journey.

117420781.value: Top Three, the Milwaukee area's best high school football players
117420781.flat_value: Top Three, the Milwaukee area's best high school football players
117420781.label: Title of Work/Project

117420893.value:
As part of our 

As part of the Journal Sentinel’s reporting on preps football we often highlight top area players. This year, we decided to try adding a video component. Our goal was to have something short and informative that could easily be shared.

Our two preps reporters, along with a photographer, selected the top three area high school players in eight categories: linebackers, receivers, running backs, quarterbacks, offensive linemen, defensive linemen, defensive backs and special teams. Each shot a series of 4-5 second clips on each player with the two reporters adding stats and notes. The resulting content was compiled and produced in Wochit by a single video producer to ensure continuity. The videos were added to prep football stories throughout the season.

Because the eight videos do not reside on one page, I've included links to each in this summary.
